snippet: Researchers found that nearly half of women with early breast cancer can safely avoid the treatment with little risk of cancer recurring or spreading in five years....
abstract: Study published in New England Journal of Medicine finds nearly half of women with early-stage breast cancer can skip chemotherapy with little risk of recurrence; researchers say by measuring activity of genes controlling growth and spread of cancer--so-called genome test--they can determine which patients would not benefit from chemo; findings reassure doctors who want to spare patients treatment's harsh side effects, although patients who skip chemo have slightly higher disease recurrence rates.
lead_paragraph: Researchers found that nearly half of women with early breast cancer can safely avoid the treatment with little risk of cancer recurring or spreading in five years.

headline.main: Gene Tests Identify Breast Cancer Patients Who Can Skip Chemotherapy, Study Says
